dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener writes in, 'Recently I've been regularly quoting this phrase about adapting to new realities and the need for re-education.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener writes in, 'Recently I've been regularly quoting this phrase about adapting to new realities and the need for re-education.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recently Ive regularly been quoting this phrase when talking about adapting to the new realities of global disruptions, global unknowns and strategic steps for future success. The key in being able to efficiently deal with the growing wave of challenges around us is in re-educating yourself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's so relevant. You know, they mention that in March and April of last year, during lockdowns, we all realized there's no silver bullet for these mounting problems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's so relevant. You know, they mention that in March and April of last year, during lockdowns, we all realized there's no silver bullet for these mounting problems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In March and April, many of us have been under different forms of lockdown and our experience shows that we have no silver bullet to quickly fix the mounting problems that confront us; but we do have various tools to educate ourselves to deal with current and future challenges more effectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, but we do have tools, right? Like, self-reflection is huge—assessing your own soft skills.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, but we do have tools, right? Like, self-reflection is huge-assessing your own soft skills.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I see a consensus among self-management and self-improvement gurus that it is strategically very important to devote some of your time to self-reflection in order to assess your most important asset yourself, especially your soft skills!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like emotional intelligence or leadership. It's up to you to prioritize what to develop, maybe even mapping it out on a flip chart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like emotional intelligence or leadership. It's up to you to prioritize what to develop, maybe even mapping it out on a flip chart.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You should identify, update and study the most critical soft skills that your boss, colleagues or friends value most about you (e.g., agility, motivation, emotional intelligence (EI), leadership). Its up to you to decide what you need (and want) to develop further by writing out a pyramid of the most in-demand soft skills (perhaps in a flip chart on the wall) and prioritizing what you should address right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's diversification. The LinkedIn 2020 report had data from almost 500 million professionals, listing the top in-demand skills.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's diversification. The LinkedIn twenty twenty report had data from almost five hundred million professionals, listing the top in-demand skills.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The recently released LinkedIn 2020 Workplace Learning Report comprised data from almost 500,000,000 professionals, mapped into a list of the 15 most in-demand soft and hard skills.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's not just about soft skills—hard skills, especially ICT-related ones, are crucial too. Not everyone needs to be a programmer, but uh, everyone should think about mastering something new.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's not just about soft skills-hard skills, especially I C T-related ones, are crucial too. Not everyone needs to be a programmer, but uh, everyone should think about mastering something new.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This does not mean that everyone should become a programmer or expert in artificial intelligence (AI); but it implies that everyone should consider mastering additional in-demand hard skills to be ready for the huge changes in the labor market that are foreseeable within the next 12 months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and remote work has really highlighted that. People found it way harder than expected after the first few weeks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and remote work has really highlighted that. People found it way harder than expected after the first few weeks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many places, the enthusiasm of the first week of working from home office gave way to a collapse of productivity and emotional exhaustion after the second and third weeks onward. Productive remote work has proven to be harder, more difficult to manage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh for sure. It requires so many additional skills, from time management to handling family interruptions during important calls.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh for sure. It requires so many additional skills, from time management to handling family interruptions during important calls.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition, there is a need for meticulous time management and people management proficiencies (well, how to handle dexterously a situation when your entire family would like to come to the kitchen every time when you would like to focus on your urgent project or on a teleconference with your boss?).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the online presence part—polishing your LinkedIn profile, spending maybe 1-2 hours a day on professional networking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the online presence part-polishing your LinkedIn profile, spending maybe one to two hours a day on professional networking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many recent studies suggest that today people should spend at least 1-2 hours a day on the Internet and social media. You should by polishing your bio and profile on LinkedIn and other professional and job search websites, and learning how to get rid of those small but annoying typos, sloppy sentences and incomplete thoughts and ideas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, reinventing yourself online is key now. But with all the MOOCs and online courses available, you have to be careful not to get overwhelmed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, reinventing yourself online is key now. But with all the MOOCs and online courses available, you have to be careful not to get overwhelmed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The power of online learning offers a lot of opportunities to fill the skill-gap, but be careful not to head out on a wild goose chase; instead, choose carefully and wisely the educational tools suitable for you. Just identifying gaps in your skill set is not enough in the modern world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Choosing the right courses is itself a skill to learn—like, effectively using those platforms to fit your specific needs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Choosing the right courses is itself a skill to learn-like, effectively using those platforms to fit your specific needs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Refine your learning process by effectively using your carte blanche of MOOCs and all those online studying tools and platforms, to choose the most efficient courses, modules and programs to fit your specific needs: this itself is an additional set of skills to acquire!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So it's really about continuous, intentional learning at every step.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's really about continuous, intentional learning at every step.
